name: Dummy Deck
description: Sandbox for testing new technical phrases before migration.

cards.sideA: ¿Cuál es la parte que más demora en cargar?

sideB.text: Which part takes the longest to load?
What part takes the most time to load?
Which part is taking the longest to load?
What part takes the longest to load?
Which one is the part that takes the longest to load.
What is the part that takes the longest to load?

cards.note:
**[102]**

For duration, we use the structure: [Takes] + [Time].

[The longest] is the most natural superlative for time duration.

~Which part delays more in load?~ (Incorrect: 'Delay' is usually transitive or implies lateness, not duration. Use [takes the longest].)

cards.sideA: Eso sería como un reinicio forzado.

sideB.text: That would be like a hard reset.
It would be similar to a forced reboot.
That would look like a hard reset.
That would be like a force restart.

cards.note: Use [be like] to make comparisons.

cards.sideA: El precio se calcula según lo que cueste el producto el día que se entrega.

sideB.text: The price is calculated based on the product cost on the delivery day.
The price is determined by the product's value on the day it is delivered.
The price is calculated according to the product cost at the time of delivery.

cards.note:
[Based on] and [According to] are perfect for 'según'.

~Calculated like the cost~ (Unnatural: Use [based on] for calculations.)

cards.sideA: Eso me tomaría un poco más de tiempo.

sideB.text: That would take me a bit more time.
It would take me a little longer.
That might take me some additional time.
That would take me more time.

cards.note:
When specifying the person, the object pronoun [me] goes between the verb and the time: [take me] + [time].

~That would take to me...~ (Incorrect: Do not use 'to' with the verb 'take' in this context.)

~That would take me a little bit of more time~ (Incorrect: Remove [of]. Use 'a little bit more time'.)

cards.sideA: ¿Cuánto tomaría eso?

sideB.text: How long would that take?
How much time would that take?
How long might that take?
How long would it take?

cards.note:
**[102]**

Use [How long] for duration. 

~How much would that take?~ (Ambiguous: This sounds like you are asking about cost/quantity, not time duration.)

cards.sideA: Nunca he visto algo sobre eso.

sideB.text: I've never seen anything about that.
I haven't seen anything regarding that before.
I've never come across anything like that.

cards.note:
Use [Present Perfect] (I have seen) for experiences. 

[Come across] is a phrasal verb meaning to find or see something by chance.

~I've never seen something about that~ (Incorrect: In negative sentences or Present Perfect experiences, use [anything] instead of 'something'.)

cards.sideA: Es solo cosa de tiempo para que ocurra.

sideB.text: It's just a matter of time before it happens.
It's only a matter of time until it occurs.
It is just a matter of time for it to happen.

cards.note:
Notice the use of [before] or [until] after the expression to indicate the event.

~It is matter of time~ (Incorrect: Needs the article [a matter of time]).

~It's just a matter of time to happen~ (Incorrect: In this specific idiom, we do not use the infinitive 'to' directly. You must use a clause starting with [before] or [until], or the prepositional phrase [for it to happen].)

~It's just a matter of time that it happens~ (Incorrect: Use [before] or [until] instead of 'that' in this idiom.)

cards.sideA: Esa rama es la que tiene cambios que necesitamos traer.

sideB.text: That branch is the one with the changes we need to pull.
That branch has the changes we need to bring in.
That's the branch that contains the changes we need to merge.

cards.note: In Git terminology, [Pull], [Bring in], or [Merge] are used for bringing changes from one branch to another.

cards.sideA: Esa tabla es la que tiene datos que necesitamos traer.

sideB.text: That table is the one with the data we need to fetch.
That table has the data we need to pull.
That's the table containing the data we need to bring over.
That table is the one which has the data we need to fetch.
That table is the one which has the data we need to bring in.
That table is the one that has the data we need to fetch.

cards.note:
For databases, [Fetch] is the standard verb for retrieving data.

~That table is who has~ (Incorrect: Use [which] or [that] for objects like tables, never 'who'.)

cards.sideA: El codigo entrante es el nuevo que viene.

sideB.text: The incoming code is the new one coming in.
Incoming code refers to the new changes.
The code coming in is the new version.
The incoming code is the new one coming.

cards.note:
[Incoming] is the technical term for the 'entrante' code in a conflict resolution tool.

~The incoming code is the new one which is coming~ (Incorrect: Redundant. Since you already used 'incoming', saying 'which is coming' is repetitive. Use [the new one] or [the new version].)

cards.sideA: El día que se hace el pedido.

sideB.text: The day the order is placed.
The date the order is made.

cards.note:
We use the verb [place] for orders.

~The day the order is done~ (Incorrect: Use [placed] or [made] for formal requests.)

~The day of the order is placed~ (Incorrect: The word 'of' is unnecessary here. Use [The day the order is placed].)

~The order's day is placed~ (Incorrect: A day cannot be 'placed'; only the [order] is.)

~The day's order is placed~ (Incorrect: This implies 'the order belonging to the day', which does not match the prompt.)

cards.sideA: El día del envío del producto.

sideB.text: The product's shipping day.
The day the product is shipped.
The shipping date of the product.

cards.note:
[Shipping] refers to the process of sending the goods.

~The day of the product send~ (Incorrect: 'Send' is a verb. Use the noun [shipping] or the adjective [shipped].)

cards.sideA: Me comí la letra 'N'.

sideB.text: I dropped the 'n'.
I missed the 'n'.
I left out the 'n'.
I omitted the 'n'.

cards.note: In a coding context, [dropped] or [missed] are very common ways to describe a typo where a character is missing.

cards.sideA: Le di un vistazo a eso, y te cuento que...

sideB.text: I took a look at that, and let me tell you...
I've had a look at it, and I'll let you know...
I checked that out, and here is what I found...

cards.note:
[Take a look] or [Check out] are the standard phrases for 'dar un vistazo'.

[Let me tell you] is used to introduce the feedback.

cards.sideA: ¿Qué tan lejos podré llegar?

sideB.text: How far will I be able to get?
How far can I go?
How far will I reach?

cards.note:
**[102]**

[How far] is the question used for distance or progress.

Use [be able to] to express future ability.

cards.sideA: ¿Qué tan lejos podrás llegar?

sideB.text: How far will you be able to get?
How far can you go?
How far will you reach?

cards.note: Same structure as the previous card, applied to the second person [you].

cards.sideA: Dame un segundo, buscaré la traducción.

sideB.text: Give me a second; I will look up the translation.
One second, let me find the translation.
Hold on, I am going to search for the translation.

cards.note: The phrasal verb [Look up] is specifically used when searching for information in a dictionary, database, or list.

cards.sideA: Buscaré la traducción de lo que quiero decir.

sideB.text: I will look up the translation for what I want to say.
I am going to find the translation of what I mean.
I will search for the translation of my intended meaning.

cards.note: [What I mean] is often more natural than the literal 'what I want to say' in a conversation.

cards.sideA: La inicialización es donde le decimos a Oracle: ¿Quién pregunta?

sideB.text: Initialization is where we tell Oracle: Who's asking?
The init phase is where we define for Oracle: Who is requesting?
The setup is where we let Oracle know: Who is the caller?

cards.note: In a database context, [Initialization] or [Init] refers to the process of setting up the session variables or security context.

cards.sideA: ¡Estoy casi seguro!

sideB.text: I'm almost certain!
I'm pretty sure!
I'm nearly positive!

cards.note: [Pretty sure] is very common in spoken English. [Almost certain] sounds more formal.

cards.sideA: Estoy casi seguro de lo que digo.

sideB.text: I'm almost sure of what I'm saying.
I'm pretty certain about what I am telling you.
I'm fairly positive about my statement.

cards.note: You can be sure [of] something or sure [about] something. Both are correct.

cards.sideA: Arriba del UNION: Reglas especiales.

sideB.text: Above the UNION: Special rules.
Over the UNION: Special rules.
The part before the UNION: Special rules.

cards.note: [Above] refers to the code lines that appear before the SQL [UNION] operator.

cards.sideA: Abajo del UNION, todos los demás.

sideB.text: Below the UNION, everyone else.
Under the UNION, all the others.
The section after the UNION, all the rest.

cards.note: [Below] is the standard way to describe code following a specific line or block.

cards.sideA: Si es necesario agregar formato para provincias que no sean Quebec.

sideB.text: If it is necessary to add formatting for provinces other than Quebec.
In case we need to add formatting for provinces besides Quebec.
If formatting needs to be added for provinces apart from Quebec.

cards.note: [Other than] is the most professional way to say 'que no sean' in this context.

cards.sideA: Primero consultamos aquí, luego acá, y finalmente aquí.

sideB.text: First we query here, then there, and finally here.
First we check here, then over here, and lastly here.
We search here first, then here, and finally in this spot.

cards.note: Connectors like [First], [Then], and [Finally] are essential for explaining data flow.

cards.sideA: Hice un nuevo amigo.

sideB.text: I made a new friend.
I have made a new friend.
I gained a new friend.

cards.note:
We always use the verb [make] for friends. 

~I did a new friend~ (Incorrect: In English, you 'make' friends, you don't 'do' them.)

cards.sideA: Es solo cosa de tiempo antes que ocurra.

sideB.text: It's just a matter of time before it happens.
It's only a matter of time until it occurs.
It is just a matter of time for it to take place.

cards.note: [A matter of time] is the fixed idiom for 'cosa de tiempo'.

cards.sideA: Que no sean esas.

sideB.text: Other than those ones.
Besides those.
Apart from those.

cards.note:
Use [other than] or [apart from] to exclude specific elements from a selection.

~Than not be those~ (Incorrect: Literal translation that doesn't follow English syntax for exclusion.)

cards.sideA: Estamos esperando que no sean de ese tipo.

sideB.text: We are hoping they aren't of that type.
We are expecting them not to be that kind.
We're hoping those aren't the type.

cards.note:
When you want something (Hoping), use [hope] + [clause]. When you anticipate something based on logic (Expecting), use [expect] + [object] + [to be].

~We are waiting that not be...~ (Incorrect: [Wait] is for time duration. For desires or logical anticipation, use [hope] or [expect].)

cards.sideA: Estamos esperando que sean de ese tipo.

sideB.text: We are hoping they are of that type.
We are expecting them to be that kind.
We're hoping those are the type.

cards.note: Positive counterpart of the previous card. Notice that after [hope], we use a normal sentence: [they are...]. After [expect], we often use an infinitive structure: [expect them TO BE...].
